segment.source: Configuring a Windows Virtual PC Image for MED-V
segment.target: Configuring a Windows Virtual PC Image for MED-V

segment.source: Configuring a Windows Virtual PC Image for MED-V
segment.target: Configuring a Windows Virtual PC Image for MED-V

segment.source: Configuring a Windows Virtual PC Image for MED-V
segment.target: Configuring a Windows Virtual PC Image for MED-V

segment.source: After you have installed everything that you want to include in your MED-V image, you can configure the image for use in Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization (MED-V) 2.0.
segment.target: After you have installed everything that you want to include in your MED-V image, you can configure the image for use in Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization (MED-V) 2.0.

segment.source: The topics in this section provide guidance for configuring your MED-V image to run first time setup before you create your MED-V workspace package.
segment.target: The topics in this section provide guidance for configuring your MED-V image to run first time setup before you create your MED-V workspace package.

segment.source: First time setup prepares the MED-V workspace for an end user.
segment.target: First time setup prepares the MED-V workspace for an end user.

segment.source: The process creates a virtual machine from the image packaged in the MED-V workspace and then runs Windows Mini-Setup on the virtual machine.
segment.target: The process creates a virtual machine from the image packaged in the MED-V workspace and then runs Windows Mini-Setup on the virtual machine.

segment.source: This includes the running of both custom setup scripts and the first time setup completion application, FtsCompletion.exe.
segment.target: This includes the running of both custom setup scripts and the first time setup completion application, FtsCompletion.exe.

segment.source: Follow these steps to configure your MED-V image for running first time setup:
segment.target: Follow these steps to configure your MED-V image for running first time setup:

segment.source: As an option, you can compact the virtual hard disk (VHD) to reclaim empty disk space and reduce the size of the VHD before you continue with configuring the Windows Virtual PC image.
segment.target: As an option, you can compact the virtual hard disk (VHD) to reclaim empty disk space and reduce the size of the VHD before you continue with configuring the Windows Virtual PC image.

segment.source: For more information, see Compacting the MED-V Virtual Hard Disk.
segment.target: For more information, see Compacting the MED-V Virtual Hard Disk.

segment.source: Customize the virtual machine setup process.
segment.target: Customize the virtual machine setup process.

segment.source: Seal the MED-V image by using Sysprep.
segment.target: Seal the MED-V image by using Sysprep.

segment.source: Customizing the Virtual Machine Setup Process
segment.target: Customizing the Virtual Machine Setup Process

segment.source: As part of preparing your image for use with MED-V, you can configure various settings on the virtual machine, such as specifying the settings for running Windows Update.
segment.target: As part of preparing your image for use with MED-V, you can configure various settings on the virtual machine, such as specifying the settings for running Windows Update.

segment.source: Specify all the necessary virtual machine settings before you create the MED-V workspace package.
segment.target: Specify all the necessary virtual machine settings before you create the MED-V workspace package.

segment.source: Before you create the MED-V workspace package, we recommend that you disable restore points on the virtual machine to prevent the differencing disk from growing unbounded.
segment.target: Before you create the MED-V workspace package, we recommend that you disable restore points on the virtual machine to prevent the differencing disk from growing unbounded.

segment.source: For more information, see How to turn off and turn on System Restore in Windows XP (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195927).
segment.target: For more information, see How to turn off and turn on System Restore in Windows XP (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195927).

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can set up your Sysprep.inf file to disable restore points when first time setup is run.
segment.target: You can set up your Sysprep.inf file to disable restore points when first time setup is run.

segment.source: For an example of setting this GuiRunOnce key, see the sample Sysprep.inf file later in this section.
segment.target: For an example of setting this GuiRunOnce key, see the sample Sysprep.inf file later in this section.

segment.source: Configure the setup process to run Mini-Setup instead of the default Windows Welcome.
segment.target: Configure the setup process to run Mini-Setup instead of the default Windows Welcome.

segment.source: You must either run the Sysprep tool by using the -mini switch, or select the MiniSetup check box in the graphical user interface.
segment.target: You must either run the Sysprep tool by using the -mini switch, or select the MiniSetup check box in the graphical user interface.

segment.source: For more information, see How to Seal the Image with Sysprep.
segment.target: For more information, see How to Seal the Image with Sysprep.

segment.source: Calling the First time setup Completion File
segment.target: Calling the First time setup Completion File

segment.source: An executable called FtsCompletion.exe is included as part of the installation of the MED-V Guest Agent.
segment.target: An executable called FtsCompletion.exe is included as part of the installation of the MED-V Guest Agent.

segment.source: By default, it is located in the system drive of your MED-V image under Program Files – Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization.
segment.target: By default, it is located in the system drive of your MED-V image under Program Files – Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: As the final step in the first time setup process, you must run this executable program.
segment.target: As the final step in the first time setup process, you must run this executable program.

segment.source: The user for whom the executable program is being called must be a member of the guest’s local administrator group.
segment.target: The user for whom the executable program is being called must be a member of the guest’s local administrator group.

segment.source: You can decide how you want to call this executable program, for example, through a script that is deployed with the MED-V workspace.
segment.target: You can decide how you want to call this executable program, for example, through a script that is deployed with the MED-V workspace.

segment.source: You can call this executable as the last line of your Sysprep.inf file.
segment.target: You can call this executable as the last line of your Sysprep.inf file.

segment.source: For an example of how to call this executable program in your Sysprep.inf file, see the sample file later in this section.
segment.target: For an example of how to call this executable program in your Sysprep.inf file, see the sample file later in this section.

segment.source: After you have completed customization of your MED-V image, you are ready to seal the image by using Sysprep.
segment.target: After you have completed customization of your MED-V image, you are ready to seal the image by using Sysprep.

segment.source: Sealing the MED-V Image by Using Sysprep
segment.target: Sealing the MED-V Image by Using Sysprep

segment.source: The System Preparation tool (Sysprep) is a technology that you can use to perform image-based installations throughout the network with minimal intervention by an administrator or IT-Professional.
segment.target: The System Preparation tool (Sysprep) is a technology that you can use to perform image-based installations throughout the network with minimal intervention by an administrator or IT-Professional.

segment.source: In a MED-V environment, you can use Sysprep to assign unique security IDs (SID) and other settings to each MED-V workspace the first time that they are started.
segment.target: In a MED-V environment, you can use Sysprep to assign unique security IDs (SID) and other settings to each MED-V workspace the first time that they are started.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For more information about how to use Sysprep, see Sysprep Technical Reference (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195930).
segment.target: For more information about how to use Sysprep, see Sysprep Technical Reference (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195930).

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: When you use non-ASCII characters in the Sysprep.inf file, you must save the file by using the encoding appropriate for the characters entered.
segment.target: When you use non-ASCII characters in the Sysprep.inf file, you must save the file by using the encoding appropriate for the characters entered.

segment.source: Windows XP expects the Sysprep.inf file to be encoded by using the code page for the language that you are targeting.
segment.target: Windows XP expects the Sysprep.inf file to be encoded by using the code page for the language that you are targeting.

segment.source: You must also make sure that the System Locale of the computers to which the MED-V workspace is deployed is set to handle the language specific characters that might be present in the Sysprep.inf file.
segment.target: You must also make sure that the System Locale of the computers to which the MED-V workspace is deployed is set to handle the language specific characters that might be present in the Sysprep.inf file.

segment.source: To change the settings for the System Locale, follow these steps:
segment.target: To change the settings for the System Locale, follow these steps:

segment.source: To open Region and Language, click Start, click Control Panel, and then click Region and Language.
segment.target: To open Region and Language, click Start, click Control Panel, and then click Region and Language.

segment.source: Click the Administrative tab, and then click Change System Locale under Language for non-Unicode programs.
segment.target: Click the Administrative tab, and then click Change System Locale under Language for non-Unicode programs.

segment.source: If you are prompted for an administrator password or confirmation, type the administrator password or provide confirmation.
segment.target: If you are prompted for an administrator password or confirmation, type the administrator password or provide confirmation.

segment.source: Select your preferred language and then click OK.
segment.target: Select your preferred language and then click OK.

segment.source: To configure Sysprep on the MED-V Guest Computer
segment.target: To configure Sysprep on the MED-V Guest Computer

segment.source: Create a folder named Sysprep in the root of the MED-V image system drive.
segment.target: Create a folder named Sysprep in the root of the MED-V image system drive.

segment.source: Download the deploy.cab file.
segment.target: Download the deploy.cab file.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows XP Service Pack 3 Deployment Tools From the Microsoft Download Center (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195928).
segment.target: For more information, see Windows XP Service Pack 3 Deployment Tools From the Microsoft Download Center (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195928).

segment.source: From the deploy.cab file, copy or extract the Setupmgr.exe, Sysprep.exe, and Setupcl.exe files to the Sysprep folder.
segment.target: From the deploy.cab file, copy or extract the Setupmgr.exe, Sysprep.exe, and Setupcl.exe files to the Sysprep folder.

segment.source: In the Sysprep folder, run Setup Manager (Setupmgr.exe) to create a Sysprep.inf answer file.
segment.target: In the Sysprep folder, run Setup Manager (Setupmgr.exe) to create a Sysprep.inf answer file.

segment.source: Or, you can create this file manually or use your company’s existing file.
segment.target: Or, you can create this file manually or use your company’s existing file.

segment.source: For more information, see How to use the Sysprep tool to automate successful deployment of Windows XP (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195929).
segment.target: For more information, see How to use the Sysprep tool to automate successful deployment of Windows XP (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195929).

segment.source: Follow the Setup Manager wizard.
segment.target: Follow the Setup Manager wizard.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You must configure the MED-V guest to join a domain that lets users log on by using the credentials that they use to log on to the MED-V host.
segment.target: You must configure the MED-V guest to join a domain that lets users log on by using the credentials that they use to log on to the MED-V host.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: When you configure a proxy account for joining virtual machines to the domain, know that it is possible for an end user to obtain the proxy account credentials.
segment.target: When you configure a proxy account for joining virtual machines to the domain, know that it is possible for an end user to obtain the proxy account credentials.

segment.source: Take all the necessary security precautions to minimize risk, such as limiting account user rights.
segment.target: Take all the necessary security precautions to minimize risk, such as limiting account user rights.

segment.source: For more information about security concerns when you configure a Windows Virtual PC image for MED-V, see Security Best Practices for MED-V Operations.
segment.target: For more information about security concerns when you configure a Windows Virtual PC image for MED-V, see Security Best Practices for MED-V Operations.

segment.source: If end users must provide information during the first time setup process based on the parameters specified in the Sysprep.inf file, you must also specify that first time setup is run in Attended mode when you are creating your MED-V workspace package.
segment.target: If end users must provide information during the first time setup process based on the parameters specified in the Sysprep.inf file, you must also specify that first time setup is run in Attended mode when you are creating your MED-V workspace package.

segment.source: If no information will be required from the end user, you can specify that first time setup is run in Unattended mode when you are creating your MED-V workspace package.
segment.target: If no information will be required from the end user, you can specify that first time setup is run in Unattended mode when you are creating your MED-V workspace package.

segment.source: For more information, see Create a MED-V Workspace Package.
segment.target: For more information, see Create a MED-V Workspace Package.

segment.source: Although you can specify any settings that you prefer, a MED-V best practice is that you create the Sysprep.inf file so that first time setup can be run in Unattended mode.
segment.target: Although you can specify any settings that you prefer, a MED-V best practice is that you create the Sysprep.inf file so that first time setup can be run in Unattended mode.

segment.source: This requires that you provide all of the required settings information as you continue through the Setup Manager wizard.
segment.target: This requires that you provide all of the required settings information as you continue through the Setup Manager wizard.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: If you have set a local policy or registry entry to include a service level agreement (SLA) in your image (VHD), you must specify that first time setup is run in Attended mode or first time setup will fail.
segment.target: If you have set a local policy or registry entry to include a service level agreement (SLA) in your image (VHD), you must specify that first time setup is run in Attended mode or first time setup will fail.

segment.source: Or, a MED-V best practice is to enforce the SLA through Group Policy later so that the SLA is displayed to the end user after first time setup is finished.
segment.target: Or, a MED-V best practice is to enforce the SLA through Group Policy later so that the SLA is displayed to the end user after first time setup is finished.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can configure the MED-V workspace to set certain Sysprep.inf settings based on the configuration of the host and the identity of the end user.
segment.target: You can configure the MED-V workspace to set certain Sysprep.inf settings based on the configuration of the host and the identity of the end user.

segment.source: For more information, see Create a MED-V Workspace Package.
segment.target: For more information, see Create a MED-V Workspace Package.

segment.source: Seal the MED-V image.
segment.target: Seal the MED-V image.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: We recommend that you make a backup copy of the MED-V image before sealing it.
segment.target: We recommend that you make a backup copy of the MED-V image before sealing it.

segment.source: After you have completed all the steps in the Setup Manager wizard, you are ready to run Sysprep to seal the MED-V image.
segment.target: After you have completed all the steps in the Setup Manager wizard, you are ready to run Sysprep to seal the MED-V image.

segment.source: To run Sysprep
segment.target: To run Sysprep

segment.source: Run the System Preparation Tool (Sysprep.exe) from the Sysprep folder that you created when you configured Sysprep in the MED-V virtual machine.
segment.target: Run the System Preparation Tool (Sysprep.exe) from the Sysprep folder that you created when you configured Sysprep in the MED-V virtual machine.

segment.source: In the warning message box that appears, click OK.
segment.target: In the warning message box that appears, click OK.

segment.source: In the Options dialog box, select the Don't reset grace period for activation and Use Mini-Setup check boxes.
segment.target: In the Options dialog box, select the Don't reset grace period for activation and Use Mini-Setup check boxes.

segment.source: Also, make sure that the Shutdown mode box is set to Shut down.
segment.target: Also, make sure that the Shutdown mode box is set to Shut down.

segment.source: Click Reseal.
segment.target: Click Reseal.

segment.source: This removes identity information and clears event logs to prepare for first time setup.
segment.target: This removes identity information and clears event logs to prepare for first time setup.

segment.source: If you are not satisfied with the information listed in the confirmation message box that appears, click Cancel and then change the selections.
segment.target: If you are not satisfied with the information listed in the confirmation message box that appears, click Cancel and then change the selections.

segment.source: Click OK to complete the system preparation process.
segment.target: Click OK to complete the system preparation process.

segment.source: After you have run Sysprep on your MED-V image, the virtual machine shuts down and is ready for use in creating a MED-V workspace.
segment.target: After you have run Sysprep on your MED-V image, the virtual machine shuts down and is ready for use in creating a MED-V workspace.

segment.source: Example
segment.target: Example

segment.source: Here is an example of a Sysprep.inf file.
segment.target: Here is an example of a Sysprep.inf file.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Create a MED-V Workspace Package
